title: email services updated now sending chart images with email
body: email services updated now sending chart images with email

title: Good way to version SQL Query for Reporting
body:
We have created a bunch of tabular reports with some complex SQL. Multiple people have access to squealy and are contributing to these reports. Writing these queries took a lot of effort, so losing them because of some unintentional activity is a pain, and I think, which is easy in current version if squealy as we have autosave feature which keeps on overriding to same the copy of SQL.

There should be an automated way to version these SQLs - basically, maintain various copies of it and let the user decide which one he needs to use for the report, maybe defaulted to latest one. Automatically create a new version with new changes.

title: Add more data formatters other than Googlecharts
body:
As suggested by @lgfa29 ,
Add more renderers to be helpful to people using charting libraries other than GoogleCharts.

title: UI for managing databases.
body:
As per suggestions from @lgfa29 ,
"Using the QUERY_DB environment variable works ok, but it's very hard to manage as the number of source DBs grow (we currently have 7). Another issue is that it doesn't allow user to be self-sufficient, only the team members that have access to the app deployment are allowed to change this. So having something in the UI to manage the databases would be very helpful. Now, I know that storing credentials in the database is an issue, but they could be stored encrypted and the key would be the value passed via environment variable."

title: Grouping API endpoints
body: Group/scope/namespace endpoints: allow charts to be grouped together so that endpoints would be more organized (i.e., create something likes /users/... where several charts would be grouped under a "users" folder kind of thing).

title: Updated readme to specify the supported python version
Review some security configurations for one click deployments
body:
Hi again,

After going trough the code a few times to make docker images and deploy inside our infrastructure I realized that this project might be being deployed with default security configurations that Django asks you to change before running in production. I'll bring them up for discussion on how to address them. The ones I have found are:

1) `DEBUG=True` Related source: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/settings/#debug

2) `SECRET_KEY` to hard coded value. Related: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/settings/#secret-key

3) `ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['*']` Related: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/settings/#allowed-hosts

I don't really understand Heroku one click deployments but I see some of the challenges to make the changes. I think using environmental variables and asking the users to change them when deploying is the way to go.

In our custom deployment I have been able to patch most of them, maintaining a parallel version of the code, except for the `DEBUG` one. When set to `False` the site starts to fail with this error `ValueError: The file 'css/bootstrap.min.css' could not be found with <whitenoise.storage.CompressedManifestStaticFilesStorage object at 0x7f49fb148bd0>.`

Hope this is useful. Let me know if something is not clear or there's something else I can do. Thanks!

title: Make parameters initializers more forgiven
body:
Currently queries with `string` and `number` parameters fail to run by default with the error:

```
__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'format'
```

As described in #228, this happens because there is a `kwargs` called `format` that is always passed in the `POST` request to save a parameter even thought it's only used to by the `Date` and `Datetime` types.

This PR makes the initializers for the parameters more forgiven, meaning it won't throw errors if unknown parameters are passed to the class, they will just be silently consumed.

title: "not enough arguments for format string" error
body: Hi, This query works directly with MySQL but through squealy gets the error "not enough arguments for format string" and I suspect it's because of the use of '%' in the format_date function call is causing problem for jinjasql. Is there a way to tell jinjasql to ignore the '%' ?

title: Issue with queries that contain String parameters
body:
Hi,

I've been tracking an issue we have been experiencing for a few hours. Basically creating a simple query with a String parameter fails to run with the error: `TypeError __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'format'`. Debugging the error shows that in file `squealy.views:155` an instance of `squealy.parameters.String` is being created using the `kwargs` json dict saved on the DB. Checking the DB shows that indeed a `format` key is being set in such dict.

Debugging the calls made by the browser showed that the front-end sends such parameter in all cases with the last value registered. However, it seems such value should only be send when the parameter is a `Date` or a `DateTime`. Hence, when the parameter is a `String` the `format` kwarg breaks the `__init__` of the class and the exception is thrown.

I think sending the `format` parameter only when needed in the front-end should solve it. I haven't worked on any React app so no attempt at a PR for now. A server side validation could be nice to avoid these kinds of errors. I'll check if I can come up with something decent to solve the issue.

Anyway, thanks! Hope this is useful. Let me know if you need further input to reproduce and fix this one.

title: How to integrate new database support?
body:
Hi, 

nice project! Can you provide a documentation on how we can integrate a new database support.

Want to test it with ORACLE and MSSQL. üëç 

Many Thanks!

title: Specifying Python supported versions
body:
Hi,

Thanks for sharing this useful project. I am currently going through the effort of "dockerizing" the code and it was hard for me to figure out what versions of python the project was build for and tested on. Through the process I realized that python 3 is not an option given the dependency `MySQL-python` which is not compatible (maybe it is worth looking into changing for `mysqlclient` which is a fork of the former one and python 3 compatible). Anyway, I think it is worth mentioning in the README.md that only python 2 is supported and other restrictions that you guys think are relevant. Thanks again and hope the input is valuable.

title: Fix for several databases
body:
Hi,

First, thanks for this cool project. Right now I'm going through the process of "dockerizing" this project for our project, so it can integrate seamlessly with our infrastructure. While getting used to the project I encountered a bug, only reproducible when using more that one database in the `QUERY_DB` environment variable. The exception was due to a missing key in line 25 of this file. I think the intention here was to delete the default query db; however, putting this instruction inside the `for` loop attempts to delete it several times (if more that one DB is specified) and the application does not start. This small change seems worth sharing, so feel free to merge if appropriate. The other small changes are just suggested styling issues. Thanks again for the project, hope my input is valuable.

title: frontend not loading
body:
When loading the react aplication we get an error on loadInitialCharts. It is receiving an html page instead of an (assume) array of the charts.
`Uncaught TypeError: response.map is not a function         AuthoringInterfaceContainer.js:209`

title: Add support for MS SQL Server
Local setup
body:
Really would love instructions on how to setup this up locally. Deploy to Heroku is cool but there is no way I can access our databases publically (for good reason). I've tried to do it on my own but I keep getting errors when trying to run the Procfile with honcho about "OperationalError: no such table: djcelery_periodictask" and it's not clear if I need to setup a different database for SQueLy or if it uses something like sqlite for it's config.

What I've already done:

* Installed Honcho to run the procfile
* `pip install -r requirements.txt`
* `npm install` in web directory
* `mvn install`
* `honcho start`

title: Adding special character constraints in chart name
Fixing view mode chart type bugs
